head.title: Advertising to the Young, At Whose Ultimate Cost?

hedline.hl1: Advertising to the Young, At Whose Ultimate Cost?

abstract.p: Linda Kundell letter responds to Fred Brock's July 2 Seniority column on advertising industry's targeting of young consumers, despite growing wealth and numbers of older consumers; finds editorial style and content of Modern Maturity magazine irrelevant, preferring Fast Company magazine (M)

block.p: In ''A Madison Avenue Fantasy,'' (Seniority, July 2), Fred Brock discussed the advertising industry's continuing emphasis on young consumers, despite the greater wealth and increasing numbers of older adults. The column drew varied responses from readers.

In ''A Madison Avenue Fantasy,'' (Seniority, July 2), Fred Brock discussed the advertising industry's continuing emphasis on young consumers, despite the greater wealth and increasing numbers of older adults. The column drew varied responses from readers.

While I agree with the column regarding the young age of the media buyers who make advertising decisions, I believe that there is another point to be made. I am at that hallowed AARP age -- actually 57 -- and find both the editorial style and content of Modern Maturity largely irrelevant to my lifestyle.

If I were a media buyer, I would consider Modern Maturity for its age demographics. But as a consumer, give me Fast Company any day. The writing can be exciting and fast-paced, with an editorial style that is ''today.''
LINDA KUNDELL New York City, July 3
